text.lat: 161.— Quum Oroetae res familiaris Susa esset transportata, accidit ut Dario regi, inter venandum ex equo desilienti, pes distorqueretur. Et graviori quodam modo distortus est, nam astragalus ex articulis exierat. Itaque medicis Aegyptiis, quos praestantissimos in arte medicorum putabat, usus est. At illi, torquentes pedem vimque magnam afferentes, malum auxerunt.
text.eng: 161.— When Oroetes' property had been transported to Susa, it happened that King Darius, while dismounting from his horse during the hunt, twisted his foot. It was twisted in a rather severe manner, for the ankle bone had dislocated from the joints. Therefore, he used Egyptian doctors, whom he considered to be very skilled in the art of medicine. But they, twisting the foot and applying great force, increased the injury.

text.lat: 162.— Quum igitur totos septem dies septemque noctes insomnes egisset; octavo die graviter laboranti Dario nuntiat quispiam, se olim Sardibus Democedis artem forte audivisse laudari: rexque imperavit, ut ad se quam primum adduceretur. Qui ubi inter Oroetae mancipia repertus est, producitur in medium, compedes trahens, et laceros pannos indutus.
text.eng: 162.— Therefore, when he had spent seven whole days and nights without sleep, on the eighth day someone announced to the suffering Darius that he had once heard Democedes' skill praised at Sardis: and the king ordered that he be brought to him as soon as possible. When he was found among the slaves of Oroetes, he was brought forward, dragging chains and clothed in tattered rags.

text.lat: 163.— In medio stantem interrogavit rex num arte medica calleret; at ille negavit, veritus ne, si cognosceretur, nulla spes reliqua foret in Graeciam redeundi. Darius vero intelligens dissimulare hominem, et gnarum esse artis, flagella et stimulos in medium proferri iussit. Tum ille professus ait, accurate quidem se artem non doctum esse, sed aliquantulam eius notitiam habere ex amicitia quam cum medico quodam habuisset. Deinde, quum rex se illi permisisset, Graecis adhibitis medicamentis et lenibus post vehementiora admotis, effecit ut et somnum caperet rex, et brevi tempore sanum incolumemque praestitit, quum nunquam rectum pedis usum se recepturum sperasset.
text.eng: 163.— Standing in the middle, the king asked if he was skilled in the medical art; but he denied it, fearing that if his knowledge were revealed, there would be no hope left of returning to Greece. Darius, however, understanding that the man was feigning, and knowing the art, commanded whips and goads to be brought forth. Then he confessed, stating that he was not precisely trained in the art, but he knew a little through a friendship he had once with a certain doctor. Then, when the king entrusted himself to him, applying Greek remedies and gentle treatments after harsher ones, he caused the king to sleep and shortly made him sound and whole, when he had never hoped to regain the proper use of his foot.

text.lat: 164.— Inde duabus aureis compedibus donatus a Dario Democedes quaerit ex rege, ‘num consulto duplex malum reddat, quod sanum illum praestiterit?’ Quo verbo delectatus Darius, ad uxores suas eum ablegavit; quibus servi, eum producentes, dixerunt, ‘esse hunc qui vitam regi praestitisset.’ Tum earum unaquaeque phiala aurum e cista hauriens, tam largo munere auri Democeden donavit, ut famulus, qui eum sequebatur, cui nomen erat Scitoni, ex stateribus qui in terram deciderant, ingentem auri vim sibi colligeret.
text.eng: 164.— Then, having been presented with two golden chains by Darius, Democedes asked the king, ‘Do you provide a double punishment for making him healthy?’ Pleased with the word, Darius sent him to his wives; and the servants, bringing him forward, said, ‘This is he who restored the king's life.’ Then each of them, taking gold from a casket with a bowl, gave Democedes such a generous gift of gold that the servant who followed him, whose name was Scitoni, gathered a huge amount of gold from the coins that had fallen to the ground.
